p: Similar trends were observed in other African cities [47], [71]– [75], although their timings were not exactly in concordance with those of Kinshasa. For example, in Douala, Cameroon, syphilis represented 13.5% of morbidity in 1923 [59] and only 0.20–0.91% in the period 1935–39 [71]– [73], an amelioration attributed to intensive surveys and treatments [72]. In Brazzaville, syphilis represented 3.0–7.6% of morbidity in the period 1930–34 [74], and only 0.33–1.11% in the period 1953–57 [75]. In the same city, the proportion PSS/syphilis also declined from 84–92% in 1933–34 to 8–34% in 1953–57 [74], [75]. After 1945, GUD incidences became extremely low in urban settings [47], [48], [70], [72], [73], [75].
